commentBody: Won me over with the clue for PUSHOVERS.  GROUP DATE cried out for a non-‚ÄúBachelor‚Äù clue (‚ÄúBand gig?‚Äù).  But overall a breezy puzzle that was fun to solve.
First one through (ever)! I enjoyed the casualness of the answers.

The clue for 40A comes pretty close, if doesn't actually get there, to violating the rule about the answer not appearing in the clue.  It's kind of like those clues saying "Word found in..."


Princess in "A Bug's Life"?  Got it.

ATTA way to go.


!!!!

This is the third time I've tried to post...don't know what's going on tonight.

First, I wanted to point out that

40A's clue is close to, if not at the point that violates the rule about not having the answer in the clue.  

Kinda like those clues that ask for "Word found in (longer word)".


Also:

Princess in "A Bug's Life"?  

Got it.

ATTA way to go.



That should be all for now, emus.

!!!

That fun ‚Äúoff-key‚Äù clue has given me a new image to use when preparing to sing a gnarly piece of polyphony, or getting ready to blast through a fiddle tune at top speed:

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not off-key, I‚Äôm HOT-WIRING this!‚Äù

Hmmm, I have always assumed a different meaning from Hamlet‚Äôs ‚ÄúI know a hawk from a handsaw‚Äù.

A hawk is a mason‚Äôs tool, a flat metal plate with a handle underneath for carrying mortar (also called a mortarboard). A handsaw is a flat metal plate with a handle on one end and serrations on one edge for sawing wood. 

So I‚Äôve learned something. 

L

This was a well constructed puzzle but the entries overall seemed too easy for a Friday.

That said, I'm relieved to see a different *way* to clue ATTA. 

I also liked the fact that two "dating" entries line up nicely next to each other in the NE: SOFT LAUNCH (as originally clued) and I NEED SPACE.

And three's company when you throw in a GROUP DATE.
Friday Personal Best for me!  Very nice, smooth puzzle!

Back when I lived in Egypt, I had a brief romance with a young lady whose family cultivated and exported dates. As she showed me around the farm, she explained the difficulty of the trade: that not very many trees can grow the fruit, that it can sometimes take a decade for them to bear, and still many of those, inferior in size and production, and that harvesting was year-round, as the trees weren't guaranteed to yield at the same time.

As we walked along, she would point out which seedling would grow to bear fruit and which would not. Seeing no difference in their appearances, I asked how she could know this at such an early growth stage.

She said she was a palm reader.

(I'll show myself out.)




cc: emu handler
I don‚Äôt know if there is a better place to ask this, but where are the new sudokus?! I always do them before bed while breasting my infant and they‚Äôre still not up. (At least on the app‚Ä¶)

I enjoyed this puzzle despite its  having lots of pop culture references with which I was unfamiliar and which I had to glean via the crosses.  I did enjoy Show of Force for STARWARS.

I found one detail in the puzzle particularly humbling (perhaps even embarrassing).  Despite being a former English major and lover of Shakespeare who reads Hamlet once a year, and despite being a moderately serious birder, I was totally unaware that the handsaw that Hamlet could tell from a hawk was in fact a heron, and not a woodworking tool.  Given the complete dissimilarity between a tool and a bird, I thought Hamlet‚Äôs pride in the achievement was further evidence of his questionable mental state, sort of like being able to identify an elephant or a whale on a cognitive test.  That sense survives, even if a handsaw is in fact a heron, because even a devoted non-birder would be hard put to confuse a hawk and a heron.

A Friday personal best. Felt like a Puzzledog Millionaire ‚Äî like every clue was plucked from stuff I just knew. 

Enjoyed reading more about the Bee hats ‚Äî definitely time to start knitting one!
I love learning a new word via a puzzle! No idea what settee was until today. Fun puzzle, plus new vocabulary equals a good Friday.

Someone please tell me where Sam E. got that Letterboxed t-shirt he's wearing in the photo. I'm a stickler for the game! Ah, yes, the puzzle. I have no idea how I solved it but I did. It was one of those that had chunks of white squares that linger until suddenly there were none left. Hearty laughs and ahas at "Everybody's opposite" (NO ONE) and "Bugles alternative" (FRITOS.) Genius! I'm only vaguely aware of Bugles but I am quite familiar with The Buggles, the ones whose video was the first ever to air on MTV, which in turn was the first to air a reality t.v. show, The Real World, way before there was ever a The Bachelor and GROUP DATES. https://youtu.be/W8r-tXRLazs?feature=shared (Video Killed The Radio Star, the video that LAUNCHed MTV.) Thank you Sarah and Rafa for gifting me a great puzzling experience. May The Constructor Force be forever with you!

Had trouble in the SE because I watch too little TV and movies.  I assumed that the Frozen character was Elsa because she must have been in the crossword several dozen times in the last couple of years.  I had no clue who ATTA is and a GROUP DATE is a weird concept. Pok√©mon cards, holographic or otherwise, will probably remain a mystery to me.   

Some great clues.  As a sometime caver in my slimmer and bendier days I'm not sure about Deb's distinction.  I went to plenty of places where the getting in was the easy part and the getting out was harder.  I should probably be thankful that I wouldn't even make it in, these days.

"The head baker is inspecting!"
"Oh no, we're toast!"

("We knead to stop loafing around!")
Has been a great week of puzzling for me - no pbs, but really nice flows. I know there are still 2 days to go - hopefully I can keep the momentum! Today‚Äôs was no exception, thanks Sarah and Rafael!
7 stages of grief? Not 5? Kubler-Ross is rolling over in her grave, which might be the 6th stage.
Another WednesdayFriday. I look forward to wasting hours and hours trying to figure Thur-Sat out....this one should really have been published earlier in the week....

"The answer to the clue ‚ÄúThe ‚Äòhandsaw‚Äô in Hamlet‚Äôs ‚ÄòI know a hawk from a handsaw‚Äô‚Äù is HERON. ‚ÄúHandsaw‚Äù may have been a corruption of ‚Äúheronsaw‚Äù or ‚Äúharnsa,‚Äù the East Anglian word for HERON." This flight of fancy may be the scholars' take, but I disagree. I read the clue to my husband, and he immediately said they're both tools. A handsaw is obvious, and a hawk is a tool used in plastering, a flat metal plate with a handle on the underside. Up in the ivory tower, they may not know a hawk from a heron, but I would trust that Shakespeare did, and so did Hamlet. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hawk_(plasterer%27s_tool)

Wish I hadn't had the GREAT IDEA to immediately and confidently place brilliant for the "That's genius" clue in the Northwest! üòÜ

And when part of my brain said, "HeathieJ, maybe you should remove the word brilliant and see what happens because you can't figure anything else out up here and that 'Show of Force' clue simply must relate to Star Wars," I replied, "HeathieJ, you NERD! I know what I'm doing!"  About 10 minutes later, I finally caved... And then that final corner fell into place quite handily!

I still finished in about half my average time, which is exciting, but keep in mind my average time is very long. I definitely solved this one more smoothly than Thursday's but I found both very enjoyable!! 

It's always interesting to me in these comments how some people find a puzzle so easy and others find it so hard and vice versa. I think that's so nice! How boring it would be if all of our brains worked the same! 

And thanks to Deb for the great videos in the column! Love the eclectic mix of Aretha Franklin and Monty Python!!  ‚ù§Ô∏è
What is an emu, as referenced in the comments recently?  I took a crossword hiatus toward the end of 2023.  What did I miss?!

As a WoW player, I have to say I got a little frustrated that 1D wasn't MMO, but RPG. 

It's definitely a bit of a confusing answer - WoW and FF XIV are both MMORPGS, with the MMO really being the thing they have in common and a fine way to define them, but 'RPG' alone is a totally different genre. 

Most of the FF franchise are RPGs, but none of the WoW games are RPGs, so technically the one thing that WoW and FF should have in common is the MMO part and not the RPG bit. 

That said, this is probably me being finicky or overly fussy about the answer; I didn't actually have too much of a problem figuring it out.
Maybe not that impressive, but this is my first Friday without any lookups! And a decent time too! This will be a good day.

Re the Hamlet quotation.  My OED gives the 'heronshaw' (=heron) derivation but remarks frustratingly, with no further elucidation, that 'Other conjectures taking hawk in a different sense from the bird have also been made'.  At first sight this might be a glancing reference to the plastering tool which some below have suggested: but when I look up 'hawk' it does give this as a sub-definition but the first instance of its use as such is dated 1700 which is of course much too late for Hamlet.

The wee furry beastie BB notes with an ARF of delight (and some egotism) that the RCA logo was, for many years, a pup almost as adorable as she: small terrier, head cocked, drawn to "His Master's Voice" emerging from the gramophone's horn. Her human agrees that today's is a fine puzzle.

The Hamlet "handsaw" is often recognized and played as a synechdoche: the cockscomb of a rooster and thereby a euphemism for the cuckoldry of Hamlet's father. (Caution! Only when the wind is in the west.) I've never run across the heron thing outside the OED, but then, these are still early days. I'll check my RSC edition of the combined works (very highly recommended for its erudition; not horribly expensive) and report back.

Thanks for the fun, my NYT friends.

A Friday crossword that I can finish without lookups is a rare beast.

Of course, most of the people posting have said it was an especially easy one.... darn it!

Since there was no theme, it was the clever clues that made this puzzle fun.

Coincidentally, while doing this crossword, I was watching Stephen Colbert... he did a bit where he named the seven stages of grief as:
DENIAL
ANGER
POPPING SOUND
COLD DRAFT
OH CRAP, WINDOW!
HOLD ON TO SOMETHING!
AHHHHHHH!

So when I got to that clue I was quite amused. :)

@deb  "...the second is more of a hobby.  Kind of like the difference between table tennis and Ping-Pong."

Low-key Will reference?

World of War Crack is how I know that RPG.

Nice one Sarah and Rafael.  See me re: the boy friend launch. I will offer the same service I gave my sisters - deep background checks.  Please note the name of my former employer can be found in the grid.

TGIF.... oh wait I do not work anymore so everyday is Friday.

Smooth solve with some interesting side trips.  Thanks for the discussions below on HERON.  My paternal grandmother called a couch a *davenport*.  

Many thanks.
Nice puzzle, but definitely more of a Wednesday feel.  The PUSHOVERS clue was pretty clever, but overall, not much to sink my teeth into.  Onward to Saturday!

Enjoyable Friday solve. Not many immediate gimmes for me, but a couple of googles and then working the crosses and it all fell together smoothly. Came in well under my Friday average. 

Puzzle find today was inspired by the clue for 57a. Dawned on me that STANDANDDELIVER is 15 letters. Well, it was an answer just once - in a Monday puzzle from September 5, 1994 by Amy Goldstein and Julian Ochrymowych*.

The other theme answers in that one were:

PREGNANTPAUSE
and
THEPARENTTRAP

And both of those were also their only appearance. 

*might do another search to see what is the longest string of letters from OCHRYMOWYCH that were ever part of an answer. 

Went down a different path on another search. I'll put that in a reply (as usual). 

..

Don‚Äôt you hate when you (hypothetically) type in, say‚Ä¶
DEtER, knowing it‚Äôs just as likely to be
DEFER, but you‚Äôll check back later, 
hypothetically,  
if it doesn‚Äôt work?

And then get the ‚Äúat least one square is off‚Ä¶‚Äù and,
hypothetically, look at the grid, 
wonder about SOtTLAUNCH,
but because it‚Äôs written vertically, 
you, hypothetically,
do not notice the *very* letter
you originally questioned?

That has never happened to me. 

Liked this puzzle very much.

I‚Äôm sorry for those less perfect than I who
had to hunt for silly mistakes.

Happy Friday all!

Random thoughts:
‚Ä¢	Rafael so far has gravitated toward two days, having seven Fridays and three Sundays.  Don‚Äôt know what Sarah gravitates toward yet, but what a lovely leap, going from her Monday debut to this Friday! 
‚Ä¢	My two favorite answers were SOFT LAUNCH and ENEMY TURF, both appearing for the first time in a NYT puzzle, and my favorite clue was the most-clever [Starts off-key?] for HOTWIRED.
‚Ä¢	It was sweet to see the classic dook NOONE and I smiled at seeing the abutting DEFER and PELT, the former sorta a silly slangy definition of the latter.
‚Ä¢	This grid design allowed for 14 long answers (eight or more letters), which made for a fun solve.
‚Ä¢	Lovely PuzzPair¬© of TUBER and CROP.

Much to enjoy!  Thank you, Sarah and Rafael, and hoping for an encore!
Forget the puzzle, there's a SPELLING BEE BEANIE?!?!
What happened to Sudoku puzzles for Jan 26? The page is still showing yesterday's puzzles.
So many fun and clever clues in this one! Really enjoyed it.

Just a bit past 1,000 puzzles, it‚Äôs clear to me that Friday is generally my favorite day. Just enough challenge to wake me up, while Thursday trickery, Saturday obscurity, and Sunday volumes can sometimes make me want to go back to sleep. This was a great example as notches everywhere and the entire southeast quadrant took a while to gel for me, but it was well worth persisting.
You say tuber, I say taproot - let‚Äôs call the whole thing a turnip.
5:48 nearly a PB

Princess in "A Bug's Life"?

Got it.

ATTA way to go.

I do like DEFER abutting PELT

Oooohh - my usual late puzzle find (unrelated to today's puzzle). This was just an amazingly clever idea. A Sunday from August 31, 2008 by Alan Arbesfield with the title "Extra Play." Theme answers: SAYITAINTSOOT ALLOTTHESAME CRYSTALBALLOT BIGOTBUSINESS SCHOOLMARMOT LOOTANDBEHOLD BARDOTOFAVON ANACTOFGODOT Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=8/31/2008&g=112&d=A ..

I
 Don‚Äôt LIKE the cutesy, clever, tricky, whatever, cluesand answers!just like Han Sollo didn‚Äôt like snakes. my same feeling. it‚Äôs taken a lot of fun out of doing the NYT Crossword!stop it already!
Great Friday puzzle Sarah and Rafael. BETALAUNCH at 11D was my final correction. Nice to see our UNSUNGHEROs acknowledged too.

The last couple of days our stats show that we completed the crossword in significantly less time than we actually did. We'll gladly accept the boost to our average, but... wondered if anyone else has noticed this or if it's just a glitch with our account?

Hmm.  A "hacksaw" is a HERON.  That is a new one on me.  I imagine the Penguin Shakespeare of "Hamlet" had the definition, but it was really Long Ago--1964/5.  

And a 'hoot' is a YELL?  No, it's not.  If I YELLED, it would call way too much attention from too many folks; therefore I would hoot-- a much quieter and simpler way to achieve my aim.  We've gotta dice these things finely.  

Read the Constructor Notes and am no wiser on some counts... SOFT LAUNCH, the back of someone's head,  what??

58A  I actually saw some of "Bachelor" (or was it 'Tarts on Parade'?)...  really smart way to find your first Ex, I'd say.  Better way to find a mate:  do post-flood clean-up and see who sticks.  

Fave:
27D....Walter Matthau shouting, "EN-TaaaaH!" Much to his comedic partner's ire.  LOL  Great start to the day!

Some fun, fresh cluing, but if the editors think this is Friday-level, I need to find a new source for crosswords. 

I am working my way through the archives, and a puzzle like today would've been a Tuesday or Wednesday 6-7 years ago.

Deb,
Aretha is ALWAYS the best
Loved this puzzle! Fun, fresh fill and really solid construction. Probably easier than an average Friday as it got me my best Friday solve time yet, but I'm not complaining.

To the delightfully fetching Susan with whom I shared a flight from BOS to LGA: I hope you ‚ÄúBeed‚Äù beyond the Panagram, Wordled in one, and made all the right Connections.  Alas, I was too engrossed in Sudoku numbers when I should‚Äôve asked for yours.
I miss Ned Rorem and the etuis .
Loved today‚Äôs column, especially Dennis Moore!

I got stuck right at the end with the Disney clues. I feel some kind of Mandela Effect, because I watched A Bugs Life so many times as a child that the VHS tape wore out..... And I will swear her name was Anna üòµ‚Äçüí´
Fun puzzle. I had been doing the "Easy Mode" Fridays, but I find that I prefer the challenge of the regular clues, even if I have to look some things up. That's how you learn, right?

Nice Friday challenge - not too hard, not too easy. Got started with "WERETOAST", and things slowly but surely fell into place from there.

I was a little triggered though by 30D, having experienced a difficult appliance issue this past week (not BEST BUY's fault though, they just sell the stuff).

But seriously, manufacturers don't make fridges to last anymore. There are several class action suits in progress with regard to "French door" models, like the one that died on us.

Fun, breezy puzzle! Ballet dancers are having a moment in the NYT Crossword, huh? Those pointe shoes are very popular of late! 

I have to say, it's news to me that SOFT LAUNCH supposedly originated with social media. Language meaning in tech certainly changes at a much faster rate than the culture at large, but that term was a thing long before social media was even a twinkle in Zuckerberg's eye. üòÇ A beta or soft launch of software... A restaurant or other venue having a soft opening... 

(Deb stated in her column "the original referred to announcing a new relationship on social media".)





Emus, please don't mind my standing on point on my soapbox this morning!

This has nothing to do with today's puzzle but I would appreciate help understanding something.

I just completed a puzzle from the archives, and I found this there:

Ambidextrous features? AEIOU

What was that about? Googling gives me AEIOU as a historic Habsburg motto but I can't see any way that would match the clue.

Got through in pretty short order (about 8 or 9 minutes under my average), but the dreaded "One or more squares . . . "

MCA is also a record label (or was), and World of Warcraft and Final Fantasy are also multi-player games, or MPGS. /le sigh

Took me 1/3 the time compared to Thursday.   I feel like I‚Äôm not gonna be alone on that one.






Bot moderators are not real.

Ms. Franklin‚Äôs 1964 recording of ‚Äú(ITSIN His KISS)‚Äù may, as Deb says, be the best, but the rendition by Phoebe Snow and Linda Ronstadt on a 1970s SNL show is a close second. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=G2phd-QgU-g

I really liked the punny clues on this one!  Usually I‚Äôm groaning or rolling my eyes at many of the answers, but most of these were really clever and made me smile. I especially loved the NW corner (which was the hardest part of the puzzle for me) with PUSHOVERS, HOTWIRES, STARWARS, and ENAMEL.

Solved it unaided, but it took me 30 minutes of hard work. In other words, a solid Friday puzzle. Nice fill and some clever cluing. Don't quite understand "Many a humanitarian effort, in brief" for NGO. How is an organization an effort? "Group behind many a humanitarian effort, in brief" would make more sense to me. But maybe I'm missing something. In any case, a fine Friday puzzle.
I thought ‚Äúhawk from a handsaw‚Äù was a metaphor meaning he could still tell who his enemies are. I‚Äôve never heard of the heron thing. Is there a source for that?

Late last night, I was wondering about Edy's and Dreyer's, so I looked them up. Joseph Edy was a candy maker, and William Dreyer made ice cream, and they became business partners in 1928. A year later, they invented rocky road. I'd say that's grounds for sainthood! (At the time, van/choc/straw was all you could get.) Many years later, the company introduced cookies and cream. Hooray for science! And Oreos.
Hooray a figure skating jump that didn't end up being an axel! (I had salchow at first because that's the second 'real' jump figure skaters learn after a waltz jump...)

I think there are only 5 stages of grief, but I only know that because of a gag. 
I once jokingly offered photos of someone going through all 7 stages of grief if they were outbid in an auction. No one did, but I learned that I'd have to make up two of my own!

(Sort of--some people split the standard 5 into more granular phases, but 5 is most common by far)
Thoroughly enjoyed today‚Äôs puzzle. Only needed a handful of lookups and the clues were very clever. Thank you!
New Friday PB üí™üèª
ENAMEL got a chuckle from me.  Great, light Friday puzzle!

Boring boring boring. Lookup puzzle.
Obscure trivia and wordplay making no sense.
Fun puzzle, but I was stymied for the longest in the SE corner by my fervent belief that the one true Bugles alternative is Funyuns.
I just want to go on record that Fritos are NOT a viable alternative to Bugles. Clearly inferior!

With apologies - way, way off topic, but a late puzzle find that is one of the oddest I've ever seen. A Sunday puzzle from November 17, 1991 by June A. Boggs with the title: "Sound off." I was able to figure out some of these but am still baffled by others. Some clue/answer examples: "Missing ring" COURTOFAPS (I got that one) "Truncated trunk covering" THELEYSOFBROADWAY (finally got that one after a search) "No big theory connector" THEWHOLESHE (got that one too) Muffled thud : MOBILEALAA (and that one) And... the last one that I got: "Buzz off" ENGELBERTPERDINCK And a couple that I still don't get: "Yell out" FIOFWATER "Don't give a ___" SINGGALLERY And there were some others. Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/PS?date=11/17/1991&g=41&d=A ..
Loved 22D - had a very memorable family trip there in 2010. I'm convinced those good memories pushed me to set a Friday PR with this one!
What a fun puzzle!  I loved it!  Clever and fun - tripped me up just enough to get the satisfaction of a few great "aha" moments.

I'm working on an archived puzzle from Thursday, January 26, 2023. There are 781 comments on it!!! WHAT!? 

I can't wait to look at them and see what all the fuss is! In my short time here (since Aug), I know if the comments are in the 500s something big is afoot but I don't believe I've seen almost 800 in any current or archived puzzles! 

But you can't have any pudding if you don't eat your meat, so back to January 26, 2023 for me!

Question from a crossword newbie:  What is the significance of a clue that ends with, ", say" as in 47 Across and 24 Down on today's puzzle?  I haven't quite been able to grasp that.

I read Deb Amlen's note in "The Morning" newsletter this past Sunday, and that inspired me to try some crosswords.  I've been binging many archived Monday puzzles throughout this week.

Very happy (and surprised) to say I finished today's puzzle without having to reveal/check any squares, though I did have to google for help on several clues!

Ugh, I was so close to a perfect solve! I had bases instead of oases and could never figure out what was wrong!
Great puzzle, thanks for the mental workout :)

Thank you for including a link to one of my favorite Python sketches! ("Dennis Moore, Dennis Moore, etc., etc." :-D ) Re Shoop Shoop song: Aretha is wonderful but I also love Cher's version: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZM5qIJdBtX0
First time I've ever been able to finish a Friday with no help.  It took me awhile with several breaks but very satisfying! Thanks
Finished this delightful puzzle with no lookups. Yay me! Wanted to put DRYCREEK instead of DIRTROAD.This puzzle was a GREATIDEA, as my 2-year-old grandson likes to say. Thanks, Rafa and Sarah!
Not too difficult, but not a PUSHOVER either. Some clever clues
Nice puzzle, but FRITOS as an alternative to Bugles? Puh-lease. As any Bugles lover will tell you, there is no alternative.

Yay!  After struggling on Thursday in *triple* my average time, today was quick and fun!    No lookups, but there was still plenty of puzzling and trial & error, with fun clues and answers.   Enjoyable!  --like  the spelling bee cap!

I've been getting by with no lookups for a few weeks now but today broke down and googled the neolithic scottish site.  Then after staring at the lower right corner that was the last remaining area, I weakened and looked up the frozen clue and the bug's life clue.  Smooth sailing then, but it would have taken quite a bit longer hard core.  I think I need more sleep.

@sotto voce 

There is a store where people can buy Games-related merch.  I didn't see that T shirt, though.

I generally use a tablet to access the Games page on a browser, but I can't find the store this way.

I picked up my phone, opened the NYT app, tapped the Sections icon, tapped "More in Games" and then scrolled ALL the way down to the bottom of the resulting page.  One of the options is "Shop the Games Collection".  

Plenty of cool things to buy!

There are four characters in Frozen that have four letter names: Anna, Elsa, Sven and OLAF.  The clue was evilly vague enough that I needed a cross to enter, and I had nothing in that corner for the longest time.

@Andrzej

That you can solve the puzzle to the point that you only have to look up trivia is very impressive to me.

@Kris T 

Thank you üôÇ

In the late-week puzzles I often start with looking up trivia, to get some crosses for the other answers - especially if the first run yields little results without lookups. Earlier in the week I usually google stuff at the end of the solve, especially in naticky places. 

It is a bit sad to know I will never be able to solve most of these puzzles without any lookups - many American gimmes are arcane mysteries to me, and they will remain so - I just can't remember all the school/sports/entertainment/culture stuff. Alas, that is my fate as a foreigner, and I am at peace with it, even if the peace is slightly sad.

That being said, I managed to complete a few late-week puzzles on my own, and it felt great üòÉ

Some of the stuff I learn from these puzzles is fascinating. I just did an archived Sunday puzzle from 2022 and I learned that nonkosher things are TREF. Why did I find it so interesting?

Well, in Polish we have the adjective "trefny," which means something along the lines of suspicious, bad, off, illegal. I never thought about the etymology of that word, but having learned of TREF i researched the origins of "trefny." It is indeed a loan word from Yiddish, and via Yiddish from Hebrew.

The cruel history of this part of Europe wiped out almost all material traces of Jewish heritage, which for centuries was a huge part of Polish culture. I am glad at least some of that lost world lives on in our language.

@David Lundy there‚Äôs (apparently, I googled after completing the puzzle) an expanded model that adds some nuance:

EKR‚Äôs model is Denial, Anger, Bargaining, Depression, and Acceptance. 

The seven-stage model is Shock and denial; Pain and guilt; Anger and bargaining; Depression; The upward turn; Reconstruction and working through; and Acceptance and hope.

I make no assessments of the relative merits of either conceptual system, just sharing that it wasn‚Äôt made up solely for this puzzle! Plus, 5 stages of grief is better enough known that it's really an earlier-in-the-week clue :-)

Electronic Moderating Units (EMU) is what the posters here call the algorithm that sometimes blocks short, frequent, posts. They will pad their responses with extra words or symbols to try to bypass the system.

EMU was used because it appears frequently in the crosswords here.

The varied ways "emu" is used to pad responses is kind of an inside joke, with talk of feeding and bribing them, etc.

(When I answered the OP, there were no responses... there may appear many saying the same thing later) üòÑ

As threatened: I'm a big Toni Morrison fan, and still have several of her books. Anyway... couldn't help but note that SULA seems like a quite friendly piece of short fill. Wondered how often it had appeared. Well... 27 times, but a somewhat surprising result: 

14 times in the Shortz era, always clued to the Morrison title. But... 13 times in pre-Shortz puzzles and... always clued as a Russian river or an island group. 

Then went on to wonder about another Morrison character with a very friendly string of letters: SETHE (from the novel Beloved*). It's a 1987 novel, but... SETHE has been an answer exactly twice - first time in 2009. 

Just as an example - one re-arrangement of those letters: 'THESE' has been answer... 146 times. And SHEET - 116 times. 

Just a bitzer prized.

@Michael Hendler - I was the organist for the premiere of one of Ned‚Äôs later works. Ned - and ernes - and every other string of letters that are called ‚Äúcrosswordese‚Äù make my blood boil when they are called such - because all of them are real
real people
real words
real things

It is only the small worlds that too many solvers live within
that make these letter-strings ‚Äúcrosswordese.‚Äù

The world is wide, rich, varied. Words are many.

I miss Ned, too, because in 2022 when he died, we lost a shining star, an energetic force, a singular presence. Ned Rorem was; and crossword puzzlers would do well to respect that simple fact! He was a force to reckon with, and largely on account of one thing largely absent now: honesty. He was honest.

@Rob Richards "Handsaw is probably a corruption for heronsaw, hernsaw. In some dialects of England harnsa is used, and it is but a step from this to handsaw. The meaning generally given to this passage is, that birds generally fly with the wind, and, when the wind is northerly, the sun dazzles the hunter's eye, and he is scarcely able to distinguish one bird from another. If the wind is southerly, the bird flies in that direction, and his back is to the sun, and he can easily know a hawk from a handsaw. When the wind is north-north-west, which occurs about ten o'clock in the morning, the hunter's eye, the bird, and the sun, would be in a direct line, and with the sun thus in his eye he would not at all be able to distinguish a hawk from a handsaw." https://www.shakespeare-online.com/plays/hamlet/examq/six.html

I came across this same site with its explanation. While I buy the etymology part of heronsaw > hernsaw > harnsa > handsaw, the wind and sun stuff is nonsense.  

The wind only blows from the north/northwest at 10 a.m.? Birds always fly in the direction of wind? Nah.

@Laura D I had the exact same reaction you did so I have to share what I found! I tracked down the original quote in Google Books that this one is clearly a corruption of and it makes much more sense! Here it is, from the footnotes of Wright and Clark's 1878 edition of Hamlet: "For the following explanation, given for the first time, of the earlier part of this obscure passage, we are indebted to Mr. J.C. Heath, formerly Fellow of Trinity Hall, Cambridge. 'The expression obviously refers to the sport of hawking. Most birds, especially one of heavy flight like the heron, when roused by the falconer or his dog, would fly down or with the wind, in order to escape. When the wind is from the north, the heron flies towards the south, and the spectator may be dazzled by the sun, and be unable to distinguish the hawk from the heron. On the other hand, when the wind is southerly, the heron flies towards the north, and it and the pursuing hawk are clearly seen by the sportsman, who then has his back to the sun, and without difficulty knows the hawk from the hernsew. A curious reader may further observe that a wind from the precise point north-north-west would be in the eye of the sun at half-past ten in the forenoon, a likely time for hawking, whereas "southerly" includes a wider range of wind for a good view."

@Merry 
Not this week (or for a while), but I've noticed it happening to me a couple times too. My all-time best time for a NYT CWP on the Statistics page displays about two minutes faster than I actually solved that particular puzzle. 

My Solve Rate in Statistics hasn't budged for years. When I first started, I left a few puzzles unsolved. I haven't done that in years. I don't do them all, but I do most, and when I start a puzzle, I finish it same day, even if I have to look up answers. So my Solve Rate should have ticked up at least a tenth of a percent since it last moved years ago. Their math is just off. 

Bottom line: don't take the numbers on the Statistics page too seriously. They're sorta right but not completely accurate.

I only know of the SOFT LAUNCH in the business sense, as it was clued. Usually it's a limited release of an indie movie. I would never have gotten that in a social media sense.
